name: Brittlewort

Identifying Characteristics: Chains of single tube shaped cells form tentacle-like branches arranged in whorls
Dark green to bright green in color; translucent; smooth to touch
Can form dense mats on the lake bottom
Biology: Colonies reproduce vegetatively through rhizoids and fragments, and sexually with male reproductive structures (antheridium) and female structures (oogonium).

Stoneworts anchor themselves to the bottom with colorless hair-like filaments called rhizoids. Rhizoids act as roots, absorbing nutrients and providing stability. Stoneworts also have the ability to absorb nutrients through all surfaces, not just the rhizoids.
Rhizoids and stem fragments overwinter in and on the sediment; growth begins when the water warms in the spring and continues through late fall
Colonies provide cover and food for fish and invertebrates; algae and invertebrates that collect on the thick growth are attractive to waterfowl
Habitat: Grows in freshwater to slightly brackish water to depths of 10 meters
Prefers soft sediments; can tolerate low nutrient and light levels
